ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned how to use Adobe photoshop and premiere pro on Mac as well as Wacom tablet. Learned how to animate using those programs using stop-motion and rotoscope techniques.
I learned all about digital animation and the fundamentals and basics of it.
I learned the basics of making good animation, the history and influences of animations, how to use Premiere, rotoscoping skills, green screen skills.
Learned lots of different ways/forms of animation: rotoscoping, green screen, and stop motion collage for example. Also learned about the importance of sou d and how it could make or break a piece.
Learned how to animate, but also how to plan an animation, how to go about tackling it, what artistic elements come into play (composition, sound, etc.) It was a great learning experience.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: online learning did not hinder ability to perform assignments, Professor was very understanding with deadlines, learn a lot
Weaknesses: theres a learning curve, lots of material put into the semester so makes it hard to fit in all of the assignments
It is very time consuming, but you get a lot of satisfaction at the end.

The strengths of the course were the tutorials on how to animate, the guest speakers who were very cool, and the breadth of our projects. The weakness was probably organization. Some of the projects earlier on could probably be shorter or eliminated in favor of leaving time for the last two projects.

One of the strengths of this class was definitely the different projects we got to work on and the related works we were exposed to. There were also quite a few cool and inspiring guest speakers who came to talk to the class.

I think the timing of the projects could be improved since we ended up extending one project's deadlines by a few weeks because of exams and other classwork but the professor was really understanding of the situation.

It was a great class, I wouldn't say there are any inherent weaknesses with the course itself. At times it can be time-consuming (but this is all Yale courses and students enrolling are explained the time factor this in the course description) but at other times not so much, which is nice.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Recording lecture portions of class so that we could go back and watch how to do something in photoshop was very helpful. Really loved guest lectures and linking videos we saw in class to Canvas
I think using the Zoom chat and encouraging class discussion was successful. I wish we could have spent longer talking about each other's work.
I believe virtual learning works well for this art class; you're animating at a computer most of the time anyway, and you can usually easily just screenshare whatever you've been working on.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, as a beginner to animation, this class was extremely rewarding. It was not easy, but I learned a lot and found the work worth it in the end. It opened me up to new types of animation and inspired me creatively. Professor Rader values ambition and passion more than technical skill which fostered a comfortable and supportive environment for someone like me who was unfamiliar with the programs. Highly recommend for anyone willing to put the work into their content.
Yes, but only if you are willing to put in the time.

Absolutely, this was a great class and I learned so many cool things. It was a good mix of practical skills (editing, premiere, photoshop, etc.) and conceptual skills (artistic practice, developing ideas, etc.). All of the assignments are fun and interesting; definitely recommend for non-art and art majors!

Absolutely! Especially if you like animation and drawing and have the time to devote to it, would highly recommend. One of my favorite art classes at Yale. But be warned about the time commitment! Animation is not a quick and easy task so be prepared to spend hours and hours on projects. But i promise its worth it in the end
Yes, I ended up making some great animation(s) that I'm proud of, and was surprised by my own advancement at the end of the course.
Yes, I loved this class and I would highly recommend it to anyone at all interested in animation or looking for a chance to grow and experiment in their art.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/a

Zoom meeting and class discussions, screen-shared examples of animation work done by real-world artists and the professor, sharing and presentation of work with peers and peer feedback as well as professor feedback
